children.value: Often, we would like to extract just those rows that correspond to entries with a particular feature. For example, we might want only the rows corresponding to the Warriors, or to players who earned more than

children.html: $10\$10$10

children.value: million. Or we might just want the top five earners.

from datascience import *
import numpy as np
path_data = '../../../assets/data/'
np.set_printoptions(threshold=50)
does just that – it takes a specified set of rows. Its argument is a row index or array of indices, and it creates a new table consisting of only those rows.
For example, if we wanted just the first row of

Al Horford C Atlanta Hawks 12
Tiago Splitter C Atlanta Hawks 9.75625
Jeff Teague PG Atlanta Hawks 8
Kyle Korver SG Atlanta Hawks 5.74648
Thabo Sefolosha SF Atlanta Hawks 4
Mike Scott PF Atlanta Hawks 3.33333
Kent Bazemore SF Atlanta Hawks 2
Dennis Schroder PG Atlanta Hawks 1.7634
Tim Hardaway Jr. SG Atlanta Hawks 1.30452

... (407 rows omitted)

children.value: This is a new table with just the single row that we specified.
We could also get the fourth, fifth, and sixth rows by specifying a range of indices as the argument.

text/html.content:
PLAYER POSITION TEAM SALARY
Jeff Teague PG Atlanta Hawks 8
Kyle Korver SG Atlanta Hawks 5.74648
Thabo Sefolosha SF Atlanta Hawks 4

text/plain.content:
PLAYER          | POSITION | TEAM          | SALARY
Jeff Teague     | PG       | Atlanta Hawks | 8
Kyle Korver     | SG       | Atlanta Hawks | 5.74648
Thabo Sefolosha | SF       | Atlanta Hawks | 4

children.value: Rows Corresponding to a Specified Feature

children.label: Rows Corresponding to a Specified Feature

children.value: More often, we will want to access data in a set of rows that have a certain feature, but whose indices we don’t know ahead of time. For example, we might want data on all the players who made more than

children.html: $10\$10$10

children.value: million, but we don’t want to spend time counting rows in the sorted table.
does the job for us. Its output is a table with the same columns as the original but only the rows
is the label of the column that contains the information about whether or not a row has the feature we want. If the feature is “made more than

children.html: $10\$10$10

children.value: is a way of specifying the feature. A couple of examples will make the general method of specification easier to understand.
In the first example, we extract the data for all those who earned more than

children.value: How much did Stephen Curry make? For the answer, we have to access the row where the value of
. That is placed a table consisting of just one line:

text/plain.content:
PLAYER        | POSITION | TEAM                  | SALARY
Stephen Curry | PG       | Golden State Warriors | 11.3708

children.html: $11.4\$11.4$11.4

children.value: million dollars. That’s a lot of money, but it’s less than half the salary of LeBron James. You’ll find that salary in the “Top 5” table earlier in this section, or you could find it replacing
in the line of code above.
is used again, but this time with the
. Thus for example you can get a table of all the Warriors:

children.value: This portion of the table is already sorted by salary, because the original table listed players sorted by salary within the same team. The
at the end of the line ensures that all rows are shown, not just the first 10.
It is so common to ask for the rows for which some column is equal to some value that the
method can be called with only a column name and a value to achieve the same effect.
nba.where('TEAM', 'Denver Nuggets') # equivalent to nba.where('TEAM', are.equal_to('Denver Nuggets'))

text/html.content:

Joffrey Lauvergne C Denver Nuggets 1.70972

children.value: You can access rows that have multiple specified features, by using
repeatedly. For example, here is a way to extract all the Point Guards whose salaries were over

children.html: $15\$15$15

text/html.content:
PLAYER POSITION TEAM SALARY
Derrick Rose PG Chicago Bulls 20.0931
Kyrie Irving PG Cleveland Cavaliers 16.4075
Chris Paul PG Los Angeles Clippers 21.4687
Russell Westbrook PG Oklahoma City Thunder 16.7442
John Wall PG Washington Wizards 15.852

text/plain.content:
PLAYER            | POSITION | TEAM                  | SALARY
Derrick Rose      | PG       | Chicago Bulls         | 20.0931
Kyrie Irving      | PG       | Cleveland Cavaliers   | 16.4075
Chris Paul        | PG       | Los Angeles Clippers  | 21.4687
Russell Westbrook | PG       | Oklahoma City Thunder | 16.7442
John Wall         | PG       | Washington Wizards    | 15.852

children.value: By now you will have realized that the general way to create a new table by selecting rows with a given feature is to use

text/html.content:
PLAYER POSITION TEAM SALARY
Luol Deng SF Miami Heat 10.1516
Gerald Wallace SF Philadelphia 76ers 10.1059
Danny Green SG San Antonio Spurs 10
DeMar DeRozan SG Toronto Raptors 10.05

text/plain.content:
PLAYER         | POSITION | TEAM               | SALARY
Luol Deng      | SF       | Miami Heat         | 10.1516
Gerald Wallace | SF       | Philadelphia 76ers | 10.1059
Danny Green    | SG       | San Antonio Spurs  | 10
DeMar DeRozan  | SG       | Toronto Raptors    | 10.05

children.value: Notice that the table above includes Danny Green who made

children.html: $10\$10$10
$10.3\$10.3$10.3

children.value: million. As elsewhere in Python, the range
includes the left end but not the right.
If we specify a condition that isn’t satisfied by any row, we get a table with column labels but no rows.
that you might find useful. Note that
is either a number or a string; you have to specify these depending on the feature you want.
, and less than or equal to
You can also specify the negation of any of these conditions, by using
... and so on. The usual rules of logic apply – for example, “not above x” is the same as “below or equal to x”.
We end the section with a series of examples.
can help save some typing. For example, you can just specify

children.value: You can get all the players who were not Cleveland Cavaliers and had a salary of no less than

children.html: $20\$20$20

children.value:
other_than_Cavs = nba.where('TEAM', are.not_equal_to('Cleveland Cavaliers'))
other_than_Cavs.where('SALARY', are.not_below(20))

children.value: As you can see, the use of
gives you great flexibility in accessing rows with features that interest you. Don’t hesitate to experiment!
